overview: This study guide summarizes key aspects of India-Canada relations, NITI Aayog's Blue Economy report, the Vital Statistics Report 2023, the Nobel Prize in Economics 2025, the Greenhouse Gas Emission Intensity (GEI) Target Rules 2025, the reclassification of limestone, the UNESCO Virtual Museum of Stolen Cultural Objects, and Google's new data center in Visakhapatnam. It includes details on bilateral agreements, challenges, recommendations, and recent developments in various sectors.
key_points: India and Canada are working on a new framework for their relationship based on mutual respect, aiming for a stronger partnership.
NITI Aayog's report outlines a roadmap to unlock India's deep-sea fisheries potential, emphasizing sustainable practices.
The Vital Statistics Report 2023 highlights birth and death trends, the Sex Ratio at Birth (SRB), and institutional births in India.
The 2025 Nobel Prize in Economics was awarded for explaining innovation-driven economic growth and the theory of creative destruction.
The GEI Target Rules 2025 set legally binding limits on industrial emissions to reduce India's carbon footprint.
Limestone has been reclassified as a major mineral to boost production and economic growth.
UNESCO launched a Virtual Museum of Stolen Cultural Objects to reconnect communities with their stolen heritage.
Google is establishing a data center and AI hub in Visakhapatnam, marking its largest investment in India to date.

important_terms.definition: Minerals essential for various industries, including clean technology and electric mobility, which are a focus of India-Canada cooperation.
Hydrogen produced through renewable energy sources, a key area of cooperation in clean energy and climate action between India and Canada.
Fuels derived from biomass, such as plants, part of the clean energy collaboration between India and Canada.
Technology to capture carbon dioxide emissions, another focus area for India and Canada in clean energy.
An event where Canada will join India to explore AI collaboration, aiming at digital innovation.
The commercial arm of ISRO, which has launched Canadian nanosatellites.
An intelligence alliance comprising Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, and the United States.
The Quadrilateral Security Dialogue, involving India, the U.S., Australia, and Japan, focused on Indo-Pacific security.
An area of technological collaboration between India and Canada, including R&D.
A focus area for technology and innovation collaboration between India and Canada.
Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement, the negotiations of which between India and Canada have been paused.
The issue of Khalistan separatists, which is a major challenge in India-Canada relations.
Sex Ratio at Birth, which refers to the number of female births per 1,000 male births, a key indicator of gender equality.
The Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques Act, 1994, which needs strict implementation to curb sex-selective practices.
Greenhouse Gas Emission Intensity, the amount of greenhouse gases emitted per unit of industrial product output, the target of new rules.
Carbon Credit Trading Scheme, a market-based mechanism to price GHG emissions and trade carbon credits.
Mines and Minerals (Development and Regulation) Act, 1957, which lists major minerals.
Illegal, unreported, and unregulated fishing which needs to be addressed for sustainable fisheries.
United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, international standards which are to be aligned for legal framework.
Deep Sea Fishing Program which aims to ensure sustainable growth, ecosystem conservation, and inclusive development in India’s deep-sea and offshore fisheries.
A ministerial forum of UNESCO Member States that sets the global cultural agenda.

processes_or_flows.title: India-Canada Relations Strengthening
steps: Joint Statement: Renewing Momentum Towards a Stronger Partnership.
New Roadmap based on mutual respect, shared democratic values, rule of law, sovereignty, and territorial integrity.
Focus on trade, clean energy, science & technology, people-to-people links.
Address challenges like Khalistan issue and strategic misalignment.
Implement measures: Diplomatic recalibration, economic integration, technological cooperation, strengthening human capital.

processes_or_flows.title: NITI Aayog’s Roadmap for India’s Deep-sea Fisheries
steps: Phase 1 (2025–28): Foundation and early growth, policy frameworks, capacity building, pilot projects.
Phase 2 (2029–32): Scaling up and achieving global competitiveness, expand fleets, upgrade facilities.
Phase 3 (2033 onwards): Global leadership in sustainable deep-sea fisheries, promote high-value products, ecosystem-based management.

processes_or_flows.title: Carbon Credit Trading Scheme (CCTS)
steps: Compliance Mechanism: Industries meet GHG targets or purchase carbon credits.
Offset Mechanism: Voluntary entities earn carbon credits by reducing emissions.

examples: Resumption of Canada-India CEO Forum in early 2026 to boost trade and investment.
The use of AI-generated 3D models in the UNESCO Virtual Museum of Stolen Cultural Objects.
Establishment of a Deep-Sea Fishing Development Fund through PMMSY.
